Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Geochemical variation of the Pacific crust subducting beneath the Izu-Bonin arc and its implications for the generation of arc magmas
Award.AbstractNarration: The Izu-Bonin arc in the western Pacific Ocean is one of the best-investigated volcanic arcs in the world and lead (Pb) isotopes are one of the foremost isotopic tracers of the recycling of altered ocean crust. It is widely accepted that there is a strong compositional link between magmas erupted along volcanic arcs above subduction zones and subducted altered oceanic crust that is cycling back down into the mantle via deep ocean trenches. That said, currently available Pb elemental and isotopic data for Izu-Bonin arc magmas and the associated subducting altered ocean crust are at odds with this model, raising the spector that altered ocean crust may not, in fact, be an important source of arc magmas, which throws into question our understanding of arc magmatism as a whole. This research will use geochemical analyses (elemental and isotopic) of new and already collected samples of ocean crust to determine whether there is a discrepancy between subduction zone input and arc output in the Izu-Bonin arc-trench system. Using a UNOLS ship, samples of basaltic crust will be dredged from the seafloor along a ~900 km transect targeting active, vertical fault scarps along the Pacific Plate which is subducting into the Izu-Bonin Trench. This transect allows sampling of rocks of a range of crustal ages, which will include samples from the area where there is a hypothesized change in the composition of Mesozoic Pacific crust at ~125 Ma. Samples will be analyzed for chemical composition and the results will be used to determine mass balances of slab input/arc output. The work will also entail a calibration of the magnetic timescale. Results of the investigation will provide a crucial test of current concepts on crustal recycling at subduction zones and modes of crustal extraction from the mantle in which the subduction processing of carbon plays a pivotal role. Goals of this research are linked directly to the science plan of the NSF-funded Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP) and will provide essential data input to four upcoming IODP drilling expeditions (three JOIDES Resolution legs scheduled for 2014 and one CHIKYU expedition that is pending). Broader impacts of the project will foster national and international collaboration among the investigators and will support two investigators from groups under-represented in the sciences. The project also will support graduate and undergraduate students who will be fully integrated into the science discovery aspect of the project. Project results will be incorporated into a 1-day workshop for teachers from the San Diego Unified School District through the NSF-funded Center for Ocean Science Education Excellence in California.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we worked to unravel a problem that exist in the Izu Bonin Volcanic Arc that is located in the northwest Pacific Ocean. Volcanic arcs like the Izu Bonin arc form in so-called 'subduction zones'. These are zones of plate collision, where one lithospheric plate - which is a tens of kilometer thick package of oceanic crust and underlying mantle - is dragged below (or ‘subducted’) beneath another lithospheric plate. Chains of arc volcanoes are constructed on the overriding plate at about 100-120 km depth above the subducting lithospheric slab. A portion of the subducted rock materials is returned (‘recycled’) to the volcanic arcs, which means it is released from the slab beneath the volcanic arcs and reaches the Earth surface again via the volcanism, usually within a few million years.

The concept of recycling in subduction zones was a very exciting discovery in Earth sciences. A strong argument in favor of this hypothesis is the observation that many studies found that the composition of the oceanic crust right at the trenches (which is right before it is subducted) strongly resembles those in the volcanics arcs. However, this compositional link does not seem to work in all arcs, and one of the exceptions occurs in the Izu Bonin arc/trench system. Here, the Pacific lithospheric plate subducts beneath the Philippine lithospheric plate. The Pacific plate has a distinct Pb isotopic signatures. Models predict that this same Pb isotope signature should show up in the Izu Bonin arc, yet the many analyses on the volcanoes of Izu Bonin arc show that they have instead the Pb isotope signature of the Philippine Plate.  Does this imply that the theory of a compositional link between the two lithospheric are wrong? Intriguingly, a study of the plate tectonic patterns of the Pacific Plate seem offers a way out of the quandary. Possibly, Pacific Plate that is now at the Izu Bonin trench is not the same Pacific Plate that is currently feeding into the Izu Bonin volcanoes, because a huge fault zone that cuts right along the trench might have displaced two segments of the Pacific plate that have a similar structure but a different composition in Pb isotopes.

In order to test this latter possibility, we obtained more rocks from the lithospheric plate at trench during a cruise that recovered rocks successfully from several locations from several thousand meters of water depths. However, the analyses showed that this crust has very strong the Pacific type signatures. This means that our study compounded the problem, and that we need to make further efforts in order understand whether the composition of the Pacific crust is indeed so diverse as the composition of the volcanic arc exists.

We also continue to compile the published data on volcanic arcs worldwide in a database in order to assess whether similar disparities existed elsewhere. Indeed, the central-south American volcanic arc, which is strung along the Pacific side of the continent, shows also Pb isotope ratios that are different from the Pacific crust. Thus, this is another important location which needs to be studied in order to understand the recycling in volcanic arcs.

 The project in the Izu Bonin volcanic arc is at the core of the PhD project of a graduate student, who collected all the data from the rock samples from the Izu Bonin trench. The student gave presentations at international conferences and is now working on papers for scientific journals. Three undergraduate students were involved, who helped with the analytical work and especially with the data compilation in a relational database. Two of the students used the data for their senior thesis projects in their final year at college and both were involved in conference presentations (one as lead author).  A Visiting Postdoc from Germany used the database for her work that resulted in two published papers. The project also fostered collaboration between scientists from Lamont/NY and Scripps, Ja Jolla/CA and with colleagues from Japan and China. A Chinese scientist who participated in the cruise to the Izu trench visited at Lamont in 2017. The project furthered the career of a female scientist with a disability.
